_description: John Lydgate, ‘Hors, Goose and Shepe’ — seventy-seven rhyme royal stanzas and envoy of fifteen 8-line stanzas

BodAsh50.First Lines:
Controversyes And pleys and disordysBetweene persones were hit ij
                    or iijSowght owt the ground by wytnes or recordysThis was the Custom
                    of Antiquyte…
BodAsh50.Last Lines:
…Yevyng example that noe manner wightffor no prerogatiffe his
                    neibur shall despyse
BodAsh50.Note:
Signed by scribe: ‘Explicit Disputacio Inter equum Ancam et
                        Ouem quod
                    M. J. Combe’ (f. 9)
BodAsh50.Attributed Title:
Disputacio inter Equum Ancam et ouum (f. 2); Explicit Disputacio
                        Inter equum Ancam et Ouem quod M. J. Combe

BodLauMis598.First Lines:
Contrauersiez pleez And discordezAttwene personez were hit tweyn or
                    iij…
BodLauMis598.Last Lines:
…Alm on vessell to speke in wordes pleynThat no man shuld haue
                    othir in disdeyn
BodLauMis598.Attributed Title: Thus endith the hors the goos and the shepe quod  leghrewell (f. 49)

BodRawC48.First Lines:
Contrauersies pleis and DiscordisA tween persones were it too or
                    thre…
BodRawC48.Last Lines:
…Yyuyng example that noman wihtffor no prerogatiffe his
                    neihbour shal dispise

BodRawC86.First Lines:
Contrauersies Plees and all discordeBetwene persones be itt one ij
                    or iij…
BodRawC86.Last Lines:
…Alle in oon vessell to speke in wordes playnThat noman shuld
                    haue of other disdeyn
BodRawC86.Attributed Author:
Iohn Lidgate Monnke of St Edm. Bury (added by hand of the sixteenth
                    century to top margin, f. 91); written by Iohn Lidgate (added by hand of the
                    sixteenth century, f. 100)
BodRawC86.Attributed Title:
The horse goose & shepe (added by hand of the sixteenth century to top
                    margin, f. 91); Explicit Amoralle tale of the horse the goose & the shepe
                    (scribe, f. 100)

CULHh412.First Lines:
Contrauersies plays and discordysAtwene personys wer it too or
                    thre…
CULHh412.Last Lines:
…yeuyng example that no maner wihtffor no perrogatyff hys
                    neyhbur shall despise

BLAdd34360.First Lines:
[C]Ontrauersies plees and al discordBetwene persones ben yit of ij
                    or iij…
BLAdd34360.Last Lines:
…Yevyng ensample that nomaner wightffor no prerogatif his
                    neyghburgh shal dispise

BLHar2251.First Lines:
COntrouersies plees and al discordeBetwene persones bien yit of ij
                    or iij…
BLHar2251.Last Lines:
…Yevynge ensample that nomaner wightffor no prerogatife his
                    neyghburgh shal dispice
BLHar2251.Editions:
Halliwell-Phillipps,  James Orchard,
                        ed.  
             A Selection from the Minor Poems of Don John Lydgate.
Percy Society
         2. London: T. Richard, 1840: 117-21 (Moralite only, 14
                        stanzas).
Degenhart,  Max,
                        ed.  
             Lydgate’s Horse, Goose and Sheep: Mit Einleitung und

COntrouersies pleys & discordisAttween persones wer it too or

BLLan699.Last Lines:

Lam306.First Lines:
…This pascall lambe with owte spott all whyteBy his passione
                    in brosa stryenes Rede…
Lam306.Last Lines:
…All in oone vessall to speke in wordes pleynethat no man
                    shoulde of odyr haue disdeyne
Lam306.Note:
Lacks stanzas 1-45, but commences with an ornamental initial as if the
                    beginning.
Lam306.Attributed Title: Explicit the hors the schepe and the gosse (f. 145)

HunHM144.First Lines:
…Off this notable ryalle hye scriptureThe blessid doctour
                    Augustyn as I rede…
HunHM144.Last Lines:
…Alle in one vessell to speke in wordes pleynThat no man
                    shulde of other haue disday
HunHM144.Note:
Begins imperfectly; missing stanzas 1-42; copied from first ed. Caxton,
                    STC 17018.
HunHM144.Attributed Title:
Sheep Hors & Goos (RT); Thus endeth the Hors the Goos & þe
                    Sheep (f. 145)
